results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Soap Operas;Television;Actors and Actresses;Emmy Awards;Nursing and Nurses;Zeman, Jacklyn (1953-2023)
results.title: Jacklyn Zeman, a.k.a. Bobbie Spencer of ‘General Hospital,’ Dies at 70
results.abstract: One of the longest-lasting cast members of any soap opera, she earned four Daytime Emmy Award nominations for her portrayal of a loving but tough nurse.

media.caption: Jacklyn Zeman, left, on the long-running ABC soap opera “General Hospital.” She had been a member of the show’s cast since 1977.

results.title: The Long and Violent History of Anti-Black Racism in the Latino Community
results.abstract: The gunman in Allen, Texas, wasn’t the first nonwhite proponent of white supremacy.

media.caption: Enrique Tarrio, the Proud Boys chairman at the time, at a rally in Portland, Ore., in 2020.

results.title: The Pandemic Threat That Hasn’t Gone Away

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Blues Music;Folk Music;Latin Music;Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Collectors and Collections;Mexican-Americans;Strachwitz, Chris;Arhoolie Records
results.title: Chris Strachwitz, Who Dug Up the Roots of American Music, Dies at 91
results.abstract: Traveling the nation to discover little-known performers for the Arhoolie label, which he founded in 1960, he earned a nickname: El Fanático.

media.caption: Chris Strachwitz in 2010. Through his label, Arhoolie Records, he documented music that came not only from before the era of the music industry but even from before the existence of mass culture itself.

results.adx_keywords: Libel and Slander;Sex Crimes;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Carroll, E Jean;Trump, Donald J;CNN
results.byline: By Benjamin Weiser, Lola Fadulu and Kate Christobek
results.title: E. Jean Carroll May Sue Trump a Third Time After ‘Vile’ Comments on CNN
results.abstract: In an interview, her lawyer said that the former president’s mocking comments in a town hall broadcast could create fresh legal jeopardy.

media.caption: After reading Donald Trump’s latest comments about her, E. Jean Carroll said that she had been “insulted by better people.”
media.copyright: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times

results.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
results.title: Asked to Delete References to Racism From Her Book, an Author Refused
results.abstract: The case, involving Scholastic, led to an outcry among authors and became an example of how the culture wars behind a surge in book banning in schools has reached publishers.

media.caption: Maggie Tokuda-Hall declined Scholastic’s offer to license her book, “Love in the Library,” on the condition that she edit her author’s note to remove a description of past and present instances of racism.
media.copyright: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times

results.title: Daniel Penny Arraigned on Manslaughter Charge in Jordan Neely’s Killing
results.abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office charged Mr. Penny with second-degree manslaughter for choking Mr. Neely to death on the subway.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Politics and Government;News and News Media;Civil Rights Movement (1954-68);Carter, Hodding III;Carter, Jimmy;Mississippi
results.title: Hodding Carter III, Crusading Editor and Jimmy Carter Aide, Dies at 88
results.abstract: As a journalist in Mississippi, he championed civil rights. He later became the face of the U.S. government during the Iranian hostage crisis.

media.caption: Hodding Carter III speaking to the press in 1979. For months during the Iranian hostage crisis, he appeared regularly on network evening news programs as a spokesman for the U.S. government. He later became a commentator on television, winning several Emmys.

results.adx_keywords: World War II (1939-45);Women and Girls;American Red Cross
results.title: My Mother Returned From World War II a Changed Woman
results.abstract: In her World War II photographs and those of her friends, my mother is laughing and bright-eyed in every single one. I almost don’t recognize her.

media.caption: Phyllis McLaughlin, a volunteer with the Red Cross Clubmobile Service, during World War II.

results.adx_keywords: Vaccination and Immunization;Pancreatic Cancer;Tumors;Research;RNA (Ribonucleic Acid);Immune System;your-feed-science;BioNTech SE;Nature (Journal)
results.title: Pancreatic Cancer Vaccine Shows Promise in Small Trial
results.abstract: Using mRNA tailored to each patient’s tumor, the vaccine may have staved off the return of one of the deadliest forms of cancer in half of those who received it.

media.caption: A colored scanning electron microscope image of pancreatic cancer cells.
media.copyright: Anne Weston/Francis Crick Institute, via Science Source

results.abstract: Kyle, Texas, is hosting a fair this month to try to break the world record for the largest gathering of people with the same first name.

media.caption: Kyle, Texas, is hosting what it hopes will be a record-setting gathering of Kyles this month.

results.byline: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Hurubie Meko and Andy Newman
results.title: Daniel Penny Will Be Charged in Subway Chokehold Killing of Jordan Neely
results.abstract: Mr. Penny choked Mr. Neely for several minutes on the floor of an F train. He is expected to surrender on Friday and be charged with manslaughter.

media.caption: After Jordan Neely’s killing, protesters gathered in subways and on the streets calling for the arrest of Daniel Penny.
media.copyright: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times

results.title: How Deep-Diving Sharks Stay Warm Will Take Your Breath Away
results.abstract: To survive as they seek food in freezing parts of the ocean, hammerhead sharks use a trick that hasn’t been observed in other fish.

media.caption: Scalloped hammerhead sharks off the Kona coast of Hawaiʻi Island.

results.title: Trump Suggests He Knowingly Took Documents From White House
results.abstract: The former president, in his appearance on CNN, misstated the law governing presidential records, saying he was allowed to take the material now at the heart of a Justice Department investigation.

media.caption: Legal experts have called former President Donald J. Trump’s interpretation of the Presidential Records Act “muddled” and “confused.”

results.title: Judge in Virginia Strikes Down Federal Limit on Age of Handgun Buyers
results.abstract: The ruling in Richmond is one of the first successful challenges to gun control laws under the Supreme Court’s landmark 2022 Bruen decision.
org_facet: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives

media.caption: A federal judge in Richmond, Va., ruled that laws limiting the age of handgun purchasers were “not consistent with our nation’s history and tradition.”
media.copyright: Alex Wroblewski for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Art;Museums;Trees and Shrubs;Content Type: Personal Profile;van Gogh, Vincent;Metropolitan Museum of Art
results.title: Van Gogh and the Consolation of Trees
results.abstract: A revelatory show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reunites 24 paintings of cypresses and unchains them from their somber associations.

media.caption: 1889 was a very good year for van Goghs: The artist produced “Wheat Field With Cypresses,” left, and “Cypresses,” seen in the conservation center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In both, the trees seem to lean against each other.
media.copyright: George Etheredge for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Illegal Immigration;Refugees and Displaced Persons;United States Politics and Government;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Biden, Joseph R Jr;Darien Gap;Latin America;South America
results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Julie Turkewitz
results.title: What’s Driving Record Levels of Migration to the U.S. Border?
results.abstract: The United States is trying to curtail border crossings as a Covid-era immigration policy lifts this week, but it has little control over the crises in Latin America that have upended the lives of millions.

media.caption: Migrants crossing the Darién Gap in September. As many as 400,000 people are expected to make this journey in 2023, according to the United Nations.
media.copyright: Federico Rios for The New York Times
